name: cocoon production, silkworm rearing | cocoons | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/19759/documentation

Inventory refers to 1 kg cocoons;This dataset represents the production of 65 kg of cocoons from 100 dfls (disease free layings). Sericulture is a well organised and to a large extent government supported activity in this region. It is promoted as a local revenue source for government and employment for the poor. Disinfected eggs are available at distribution centres where farmers can collect them at appropriate time and establish them at their rearing centres, where they have a mulberry garden adjacent to silkworm rearing hall (75 m2)

Activities start from reception of eggs.


This activity ends with produced 1 kg  cocoons. The datasets includes use of water and disinfectants, mulberry leaves consumption, electricity consumption for heat and light, and plastic tray. Emissions from disinfectants are not modelled while potential N2O emissions from silkworms are modelled based in results from other insects.
category: A:Agriculture, forestry and fishing/01:Crop and animal production, hunting and related service activities/014:Animal production/0149:Raising of other animals

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Average based on data collected from farmer at Guna district in the state of Madhya Pradesh (Central India). Data was also collected from Manager of District Coocoon bank, which is Government operated cocoon distribution centre.Sericulture is a well organised and to a large extent government monitored activity to promote it as a local revenue source for goverment and employment for the poor.
processDocumentation.samplingDescription:
Field data. Farmers and representatives from cocoon bank were interviewed to provide data based on the representativeness of currently used technology, and their willingness to participate. 
Data has been supplemented with information from literature.
Literature Sources: Gururaj, S.R. & Magadum, D.S.B., 2009. YOUNG AGE SILKWORM REARING - TRAINERâ€™SGIUIDE,(P 9)
Sivaprasad, V. et al., 2015. Commercial Chawki Rearing, Mysore (P-13)

exchanges.description: Cocoons are not dried in this process, hence wet weight and properties are considered here

exchanges.description:
According to data collected circe 0.002557 m3 of wastewater are produced in this process. Assuming a strong wastewater composition (FAOSTAT), direct emissions to a surface water body are modelled for: Dissolved solids, Suspended solids, Nitrogen (as N), Phosphorus (as P), Chloride, Grease (oils, non fossil) and BOD5. Alkalinity of water is reported to be 200 mg/L as CaCO3.

Composition (mg/L): Dissolved solids (850), Suspended solids (350), Nitrogen-as N (85), Phosphorus-as P (20), Chloride (100), Grease-oils, non fossil (150) and BOD5 (300).
Total emission (kg): Dissolved solids (0.002173552), Suspended solids (0.000894992), Nitrogen-as N (0.00022), Phosphorus-as P (0.00005), Chloride (0.00026), Grease-oils, non fossil (0.00038) and BOD5 (0.00077).

Reference:Wastewater treatment and use in agriculture - FAO irrigation and drainage paper 47, Chapter 1, Wastewater characteristics and effluent quality parameters, accessed at: http://www.fao.org/docrep/t0551e/t0551e03.htm#TopOfPage on 13 of April 2018.

Taking into account the parameters in Astudillo et al. (2014) it is 7.83 g CO2eq / kg cocoon from N2O emissions, This is divided by the GWP of N2O used in that publication (298). Reference: http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0959652614005939

sum of electricity used for heaters and lighting. Utilities considred here as the process is dependent on it. Heaters are only used during winters to maintain the temprature at aorund 23-25 degree C. This is primary data collected through interview.

the rearing process produces a lot of organic waste, (unfed leaves and excreta of silkworms). This is estimated from  In Astudillo et al. 2014, this was estimated to be about  4.27 kg of organic waste per kg cocoon on a dry basis, approximately double in wet basis.
